title: RL34447
content: Houses of worship with 501(c)(3) status are exempt from federal income taxes and can receive tax-deductible contributions, but they are prohibited from participating in political campaigns. Violating this rule can lead to revocation of their 501(c)(3) status or taxation on political expenditures. Only two churches have lost their status for campaign intervention, including the Church at Pierce Creek in New York. Other religious organizations like Christian Echoes National Ministry have also faced revocation. The Johnson Amendment, named after Senator Lyndon Johnson, prohibits 501(c)(3) organizations from participating in political campaigns. Some religious organizations, including Christian Echoes National Ministry, have had their 501(c)(3) status revoked for violating this rule. The provision was introduced in 1954 and has been enforced through settlement agreements with the IRS. IRC Section 7611 provides rules for IRS inquiries into houses of worship that may no longer qualify for 501(c)(3) status. An "appropriate high-level Treasury official" must reasonably believe, based on written facts, that an inquiry is necessary. The IRS must provide written notices to the house of worship, explaining the inquiry's subject matter and concerns. If the entity's response is inadequate, the IRS can proceed to examine its records and activities, providing a second notice with details of the examination. Under IRC Section 7611, an "appropriate high-level Treasury official" must reasonably believe that a house of worship may no longer qualify for 501(c)(3) status before an inquiry can begin. The inquiry must include a description of the records and activities being examined, an offer for a conference to resolve concerns, and must be completed within two years. Approval from IRS counsel is required for any revocation of 501(c)(3) status, notice of deficiency, or tax assessment. Further inquiries and examinations are limited within a five-year period. Some argue that the political campaign prohibition for churches violates First Amendment rights, although the Supreme Court has not addressed this issue. Two U.S. Courts of Appeals have upheld the prohibition against First Amendment challenges. The Tenth Circuit rejected the district court's ruling that lobbying and campaign activity restrictions violated First Amendment rights for a nonprofit religious organization. The court held that the limitations did not infringe on the organization's Free Exercise Clause rights, only denying tax-exempt status in accordance with compelling interests. The Tenth Circuit upheld the lobbying and campaign activity limitations, stating that they did not violate the First Amendment. The court emphasized that tax-exempt status is a privilege, not a right, and found that the restrictions did not infringe on the organization's free speech rights. The court justified the limitations based on the principle of separation and neutrality between church and state, ensuring that government does not indirectly support organizations involved in legislative goals or candidate elections. The Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA) prohibits corporations—including incorporated 501(c)(3) religious entities—from using general treasury funds to make contributions in connection with federal elections. The IRC prohibits all 501(c)(3) organizations, regardless of corporate status, from making such contributions. The Supreme Court ruling in Citizens United v. FEC invalidated prohibitions in FECA on corporations and labor unions using general treasury funds for independent expenditures and electioneering communications. This decision does not significantly impact houses of worship with 501(c)(3) status due to tax code prohibitions. The activities regulated by FECA and the IRC may differ, such as issue advocacy communication timing. Legislation has been introduced in the 112th Congress to repeal the IRC provision prohibiting these organizations from engaging in campaign activity. If enacted, houses of worship could engage in campaign activity without risking their tax-exempt status, as long as it is not their primary activity. The bill introduced in the 112th Congress aims to allow houses of worship with 501(c)(3) status to engage in campaign activity without jeopardizing their tax-exempt status, as long as it is not their primary activity. This legislation does not change the current reporting requirements for these organizations, meaning they are not required to report campaign activities to the IRS. Additionally, the bill specifies that it does not affect the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971.
